block.p: A Town Searches Its Soul The stabbing death of a white man by a Vietnamese native, which some say was self-defense, prompts soul-searching in a Washington resort town about racial hatred.
PAGE 24
Doubts About Gore in South Vice President Al Gore is hoping to avoid a Southern shutout, but he seems to be struggling even in states where he hoped to do well.

Diamond Nightmares Though loath to admit it, some diehard New York baseball fans are in a cold sweat at the thought of a Subway Series.
PAGE 41
Irreconcilable Differences Getting negotiators to agree is not enough: Why peace between Israel and the Palestinians has been so elusive.
WEEK IN REVIEW
Driven by Design Design is capturing the public imagination in a way no creative field has in decades.
ARTS & LEISURE
Durable Saul Bellow At 85 and going strong, Saul Bellow has lived much more than most novelists; James Atlas's biography of him took a long time and many pages.
BOOK REVIEW
How Americans Spend In these flush economic times, America is very much a nation of big spenders. But what makes them part with their money, and why? A special issue.
MAGAZINE

Private Land, Public Realm For the first time, a study identifies plazas, walkways and atriums in New York City that earned their owners zoning bonuses, and rates their use to the public. With a map showing all 316 buildings in Manhattan with such spaces.
REAL ESTATE
